did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Joe Conzo, Jr. photographs and ephemera, 1977-present.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Collection includes photographic film negatives, 4x6 and 8x10 prints, proof and contact sheets, large format finished prints, and associated ephemera. Many of the images have been digitized and arrived on hard drives.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Joe Conzo, Jr. is an American photographer, born in the Bronx, New York City in 1963. In 1978, while attending South Bronx High School, Conzo became friends with members of the Cold Crush Brothers, an important and influential early Hip Hop group which included DJs Charlie Chase and Tony Tone and MCs Grandmaster Caz, JDL, Easy AD, and Almighty KayGee. Conzo became the group's personal photographer, documenting their live performances at the T-Connection, Disco Fever, Harlem World, the Ecstasy Garage, and the Hoe Avenue Boy's Club. He also took pictures of other Hip Hop artists and groups, including The Treacherous 3, The Fearless 4, and The Fantastic 5. As a result, he captured some of the earliest images of Hip Hop culture, along with every day street scenes and Latin music performances and events between 1977 and 1984. Joe Conzo is currently a Medical Technician with the New York City Fire Department, and is active in leadership of the EMTs labor union. He continues to photograph Hip Hop and other music performers both nationally and internationally.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Collection includes photographic film negatives, 4x6 and 8x10 prints, proof and contact sheets, large format finished prints, and associated ephemera. Many of the images have been digitized and arrived on hard drives.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Access to negatives restricted to the permission of the curator.
Access to Box 4, Folder 3 restricted to permission of the curator.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p: Negatives closed for research, access to those materials is available through the digital collection.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Joe Conzo, Jr. photographs and ephemera, #8091. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: Associated online resource: call number TR654.C66.

did.unittitle: 8 x 10 Prints - Contemporary to original photo date

scopecontent.p: Broken fire hydrant and empty bottle of malt liquor
Posed shot of Joe holding flashbulbs with a hat covering his face

Paul Newman chasing Joe and other protestors off of the set of the film Fort Apache, The Bronx. This was Joe's first published photograph; it appeared in the New York Post, March 25 1980. The film set was located at Eagle Ave. and Westchester Ave. in the Bronx. Community activists were protesting the film's negative depiction of minorities and of the Bronx in general. This print is accompanied by a mounted photocopy of the New York Post article with note from "Reyes II" of the UBP (United Bronx Parents) Photography Workshop congratulating Joe on its publication.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers and fans at T-Connection

scopecontent.p: Early Joe Conzo photos of Cold Crush-- possibly the first. Also several shots of people from the audience (friends of Joe Conzo); one shot of Tony Tone with his mother; one shot of Cold Crush's DJ equipment.
The Fearless Four onstage; Money Ray, Joe Conzo, Easy A.D. and friends in the audience.

unittitle.emph: Cold crush Brothers, South Bronx H.S.

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush performance at South Bronx High School in 1980 with additional pictures of the Treacherous 3, Kool Moe Dee, Cracker Jack of the Casanova Crew, and King. A photograph from this show was used (without permission) in the film CB4.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers, South Bronx H.S. Prom

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush performing at the 1980 South Bronx High School prom. Joe Conzo, Easy A.D., and Tony Tone attended South Bronx HS; this was Joe's prom.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush van ride (Tony Tone's van) upstate NY

scopecontent.p: Joe Conzo, Cold Crush Brothers, Nana (Tony Tone's cousin), King (Tony Tone's brother), Money Ray, and [Kool Moe Dee], driving upstate in Tony Tone's van. Joe claims that Kool Moe Dee was not present in the van, so we are waiting for identification on the last individual.
Cold Crush performance at the Skatin' Palace in 1981.
Cold Crush backstage at the Skatin' Palace, 1981.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush and Loose Bruce, Club Negril's

scopecontent.p: Shots of Cold Crush performing and some shots of b-boy Loose Bruce dancing. Before Cold Crush J.D.L. and Grand Master Caz performed together as the Notorious Two. There are several silhouette shots of Caz and J.D.L. together in this group, and though this is a Cold Crush performance, Joe Conzo refers to these photos in this group as shots of the Notorious Two.

unittitle.emph: Charlie Chase, Afrika Bambaataa, Grand Mixer DST, Kips Bay Boys Club

scopecontent.p: Charlie Chase, Afrika Bambaataa, and Grand Mixer DST at the Kips Bay Boys Club, 1981.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush, Electricians' Hall (Amityville, Long Island)
Cold Crush at the Fever (167th and Jerome)
Cold Crush Harlem World Easter Show

scopecontent.p: This group of photos is a very detailed recording of the 1981 performance of Cold Crush at Harlem World. Shots from this show are identifiable because of the use of a smoke machine onstage.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush and the Treacherous Three, Norman Thomas H.S

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush and the Treacherous Three perform at Norman Thomas High School in 1981. Also several posed shots of both groups in front of the gym bleachers.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush upstairs at Harlem World

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush rehearsing upstairs at Harlem World before a show in 1981.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush, Hoe Ave. Boys Club

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush performance at Roosevelt H.S. with pictures of crowd and members.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers and Fantastic Romantic Five 'Wild Style' Rehearsals

scopecontent.p: The Cold Crush Brothers and Fantastic Romantic 5 rehearsing for Charlie Ahearn's film 'Wild Style' basketball court scene. The basketball court was located at either Ryer Ave. and 182nd Street in the Bronx OR at Intermediate School 115 (Morris Ave. and 184th). Some shots focus on Kevie Kev and Whipper Whip (of the Fantastic Five); Charlie Ahearn and Fab Five Freddy are also visible.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers and Charlie Ahearn signing the 'Wild Style' contract, Dixie Club

scopecontent.p: Cold Crush and Charlie Ahearn sign the contract for Ahearn's film Wild Style.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers Hoe Ave Boys Club
Cold Crush Brothers and Fantastic Romantic Five battle, Harlem World

scopecontent.p: Pictures of the Cold Crush Brothers performance in the famous battle with the Fantastic Romantic Five.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush Brothers, South Bronx High School

scopecontent.p: Tony Tone, DJ Red Alert, J.D.L., Grand Master Caz, Mr. Biggs (of the Soul Sonic Force) and Busy Bee at the 1981 Zulu Nation Anniversary.
Three portrait photos taken on Prospect Ave. and 156th street in the Bronx.
A large number of posed group, solo, and duo shots of the Cold Crush Brothers. These portraits were taken in a makeshift studio in the back room of United Bronx Parents in the Bronx.
Posed and performance shots of Cold Crush Brothers (in suits)
Wide shots of the stage during a Cold Crush performance at Harlem World

unittitle.emph: Norman Thomas High School Senior Boat Ride

scopecontent.p: From Cold Crush performance on the Norman Thomas High School senior trip to Bear Mountain on the Hudson River Day Line. (This line was later bought by the Circle Line). Also included: one shot of LA Sunshine (of the Treacherous Three) with members of Cold Crush; several shots of students/audience on boat

unittitle.emph: Treacherous Three Anniversary - Cold Crush Brothers, Jazzy Ace and D-Ski, Wayne and Charlie; Harlem World

scopecontent.p: Shots of performances by Cold Crush, Jazzy Ace and D-Ski, and hip hop ventriloquist act Wayne and Charlie at the Treacherous Three anniversary in either 1982 or 1983. Also: two pictures of Tony Tone's brother King in the crowd.

unittitle.emph: Cold Crush - Wild Style Filming, Dixie Club,

scopecontent.p: These pictures show the filming of a scene for Wild Style. The film crew is visible in the crowd.
Photos of unidentified individuals from a UBP picnic in 1978. Also one picture of Joe's girlfriend Teresa.

Paul Newman chasing Joe and other protestors off of the set of the film Fort Apache, The Bronx. This was Joe's first published photograph; it appeared in the New York Post, March 25 1980. The film set was located at Eagle Ave. and Westchester Ave. in the Bronx. Community activists were protesting the film's negative depiction of minorities and of the Bronx in general.

unittitle.emph: Tito Puente and Machito outdoor performance

scopecontent.p: Photos of Tito Puente and Machito on stage outdoors in the Bronx. Several photos of Tito and Machito performing, some shots of the crowd, and two photos of filmmaker Carlos Ortiz and his film crew. Ortiz was one of Joe Conzo's mentors, and directed a documentary about Machito.

unittitle.emph: Vigil for John Lennon at Strawberry Fields, Central Park

scopecontent.p: Two young girls mourning John Lennon in Central Park

unittitle.emph: Mean Machine' outdoor event, 3rd Ave Hub

scopecontent.p: Photos of Mean Machine during an outdoor event sponsored by the radio station 92 KTV at the 3rd Ave Hub in the Bronx. The photos include a few pictures of the group onstage, but most are of individuals in the audience.

unittitle.emph: Government Cheese handout, United Bronx Parents

scopecontent.p: Residents of the Bronx waiting in line to pick up free government cheese at United Bronx Parents.

Photos of various locations in the Bronx in various locations, particularly along Prospect Avenue above 149th St. Some of the photos depict early graffiti and street art. Many street portraits of unidentified individuals. One print depicts a 1978 protest of funding cuts for sports programs in South Bronx high schools. One shot of a vacant lot at Westchester Ave. and Brook Ave. was used as the cover image for the book Next Stop: Growing Up Wild Style by Ivan Sanchez (Touchstone, 2008).

Photos of everyday street scenes scattered all over the Bronx. Photos depicting stores, street vendors, people walking, and children playing. There are also several shots of a film crew working on an unidentified documentary.

These photos depict demolished buildings and vacant lots-- the devastation of the South Bronx. Also included are photos from the Cloisters in Manhattan, Lincoln Hospital, and the 1981 or 1982 Puerto Rican Day parade.

This roll includes Joe's earliest black and white shots-- pictures of his classmates at Junior H.S 149 from 1976. Also included are pictures of Joe's girlfriend Teresa and her nieces, Joe's girlfriend Maria, Abigail and Rachel (two sisters from the Bronx), Sonya, Tiny and Herman (Tiny is the daughter of Carmen Arroyo, the first Hispanic woman in NY assembly), Sandy Santiago and Dr. Sporano from Lincoln Hospital, Carlos, Cappy, Roseann Pascale (a college friend of Joe's who now produces the television show Miami Ink), David, and several unidentified children from the South Bronx. The last photo in this group is two unidentified individuals who may have been radio DJs; they seem to be in a radio station or record store.

These portraits are of various people in or outside the office of United Bronx Parents including. Named individuals include Reuben and Yvette, Evelina Antonetty (Founder of U.B.P. and Joe Conzo's grandmother), and Donald Antonetty. There are also several color shots from a UBP party in 1976, including a shot of two vendors who provided food for a summer lunch program.

These photos depict places and people from Joe Conzo's life in the late 1970s and early 1980s. There are several self-portraits, photos of his son Angel's baptism, his ex-wife Gina Martinez, his first car (a 1976 Chevy Malibu), his cat, his apartment, Lorraine Montenegro (Joe's mother) and her boyfriend Sailor, a basement clubhouse that he shared with his friends, Joe's girlfriend Doris, Joe's family members Donnie (uncle), Eric Kane (brother), Lorraine Montenegro (mother), and Anita (aunt), Joe and friends at Coney Island, Joe's "wedding" to an unknown woman in 1981, Joe and Rolando Arroyo (son of Carmen Arroyo) at Michelangelo Apartments in 1980, and one photo from the South Bronx High School 1980 senior trip to a dude ranch in upstate New York. There are also several self-portraits (including one taken at the studio of Tom Rose Joe's mentor, at Riverside and 92nd St. in Manhattan). Also included are some of Joe's lighting experiments.

The contact sheets are numbered 1-35, but the photos are in no particular order on them. Joe's negatives were kept in a box in his grandmother's house for several years, and they were not organized before the 4x6 prints were developed.

unittitle.emph: Hip Hop Doc - Kool Moe Dee

did.unittitle: Series II. Contact Sheets, Negatives, and Slides

arrangement.p: File subjects are listed out for contact sheets and negatives as labeled by Joe Conzo. Numerous unlabeled sheets are included in each case and are not listed out in the guide.
Most contact sheets have been scanned and are available through ARTstor's Shared Shelf Commons. Item ID number ranges for each case are listed out where applicable.

accessrestrict.p: Folder 3 from box 4 is restricted to the permission of the curator.

scopecontent.p: Includes photocopies of handwritten lyrics and an unsigned copy of a 1982 contract between CC4 and Frost Belt International Recording Enterprises.
Includes article on early hip hop featuring Conzo photographs.
Includes flyers for performances at T-Connection, Ecstasy Garage Disco, and Skatin' Palace.
Contains magazines related to latinx culture, as well as an issue of "That 70s Show: New York City in the 1970s" which includes writing and photos by Conzo.

Clipping from March 25, 1980 issue of the New York Post, featuring Joe Conzo's photo of Paul Newman. Includes inscription: "UBP's first published student photographer, Joey Kane. Congratulations from the UBP Photography Workshop! - Reyes II"

did.unittitle: Series IV. Born in the Bronx
Prints from "The Breaks: Stylin' and Profilin'"
